content.content: Unfortunate but it is also interesting / makes sense how they paid back onchain loans first. So the risk to Maker was mitigated before as they paid back their loans.    The Block    Crypto lender Celsius declares Chapter 11 bankruptcy in New York Crypto lender Celsius has filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy, according to court filings.
Was it purely due to the overcollateralization incentive or was there a higher claim placed for onchain loans? I did not find it in the article…
It’s overcollaterized but can imagine for protocols that conducted undercollaterized or credit based loans, it might been detrimental

Not necessarily. In Chapter 11 cases, there is the concept of a “preference period” (90 days before a bankruptcy filing). A trustee may void payments made during the 90 period before the bankruptcy filing. 11 U.S. Code § 547 - Preferences | U.S. Code | US Law | LII / Legal Information Institute I have not traced the timing of Celsius’ payments to the Maker vault, but this may raise an interesting question of 1st impression.
They paid back within a month before filing I think

So there we have an open legal question. Actually, sometimes it does make sense to have a lawyer available to identify this type of issue and, with Maker token holder support, seek external advice. Maybe the answer will be unclear or maybe there is not an issue. We actually don’t know at this moment. But, US bankruptcy courts have very powerful statutory tools available to support the rehabilitation of Chapter 11 applicants.
Articles I’m reading suggest that may not apply to overcollateralized loans.

To be sure, the US Bankruptcy Code (11 USC Sec. 547(b)) identifies specific exceptions to the bankruptcy trustee’s power to void a transaction. I do not know enough of the Celsius’s payments to Maker to know whether any of the exceptions apply. An analysis will be very fact specific. This might be something to seek legal guidance on.
At least they went bankrupt just after paying off the Vault they had open at Maker.

I mean granted, as it’s over collaterized, it would just mean the protocol taking more fees from it. I guess there was potential risk of large WBTC vault getting liquidated and potentially overwhelming liquidation system
Yes, I meant it more in that sense, for Maker it has been beneficial for them to continue, but on the general side, already liquidating in spot more than $5 million is usually detrimental.
its sad to see many folks losing money on Celsius, but these poor business models need to fail for DeFi and crypto to evolve and succeed.  Its a Darwinian game
